text: Hey everyone, so I was watching a tutorial on Flux, and in the example of the tutor he writes `model.W.grad` ... But when I try to reproduce what he is doing, I get an error, saying that `model.W` does not have this attribute `grad`. Besides, I notice that in his case, `model.W`  is a tracked array, and mine isnt. Any ideas on why this might be happening? Perhaps new versions of Flux changed things?

elements.text: Hey everyone, so I was watching a tutorial on Flux, and in the example of the tutor he writes
model.W.grad
... But when I try to reproduce what he is doing, I get an error, saying that
model.W
does not have this attribute
grad
. Besides, I notice that in his case,
model.W
is a tracked array, and mine isnt. Any ideas on why this might be happening? Perhaps new versions of Flux changed things?

text: Flux switched to Zygote around 0.10.x, which doesn't use tracked arrays (and thus doesn't store gradients in a `.grad` property)

elements.text: Flux switched to Zygote around 0.10.x, which doesn't use tracked arrays (and thus doesn't store gradients in a
.grad
property)

text: Oooh, that is what I thought might be happening. Is just that the tutorial is from july 2020, so I was hoping it was recent.

elements.text: Oooh, that is what I thought might be happening. Is just that the tutorial is from july 2020, so I was hoping it was recent.
Things change fast

text: v0.10.0 came out at the end of november 2019...

elements.text: v0.10.0 came out at the end of november 2019...
That's weird o.O

text: did the tutorial say which version of Flux was used?

no
maybe it was a repost

text: Granted it took a while for Flux/Zygote to stabilize (some might say it's still not), but I would expect at least a mention 9 or so months late
